author: gcolvin
content:
Hmm.  From the abstract it doesn't look that promising:

> ... optimized for a specific benchmark program and a specific CPU... 

> ... improved the execution speed... between 0.8% and 23.0% ...

> ... solutions do not generalize across different machines ... highly specific to a microarchitecture.

In the conclusion they propose 
> ... to find a more general order across programs by optimizing for multiple programs.
which it seems would likely reduce the typical execution speed improvement for any given program or machine.

author: gcolvin
content: A long while back Martin and I were working on putting the code for short, common opcodes (like push and pop) directly in the interpreter loop where the compiler could see and optimize them, and moving the more complex ones (like arithmetic) into functions that got called indirectly through an array.  Not sure what came of it.
